I think drugs should remain illegal.

Cheap drugs means more drugs for the same money, which could lead to more addiction problems. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
Sensible legal drug policy would uses taxes to keep prices equal or slightly below current black market prices to keep that from occuring. So legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.

This is an argument of the ends justifying the means. The government could generate more income by simply taking everyone's money by force - that doesn't make it a good choice. I believe drugs should remain illegal.

This argument is prematurely claiming that the means \(the legislation of drugs\) is immoral. Whether it is moral or immoral should be decided after it has already happened and we can measure the impact on our society. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
This is a false equivalency. Providing a service or good to bolster economic growth is not the same as being forced to give your money to the government. I believe all drugs should be legal.
Professional addiction treatment is usually [expensive](https://www.addictioncenter.com/rehab-questions/cost-of-drug-and-alcohol-treatment/). I think legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
Addiction treatment isn't actually very expensive or costly, and is likely to be clinically simpler to resolve than is widely assumed. I think drugs should remain illegal.

I believe drugs should remain illegal.

When drugs are legalised, people who are addicted may feel more comfortable seeking help and support as they won't be viewed as criminals in the way they currently are. So legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Criminalizing and stigmatizing drug users/addicts increases the vulnerability of vulnerable populations. Prostitutes, who are already subject to stigmatization, suffer from a [second stigma](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/237733588_Prostitution_Drug_Use_and_Coping_with_Psychological_Distress) by taking drugs as coping mechanism. I think all drugs should be legal.

It may be difficult to find and employ the right kind of medical professionals who can support the user's needs effectively \(helping the user in dealing with trauma from their past & their conditioning from childhood\) I think legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.

It is not a matter of "feeling comfortable" seeking help, it's that seeking help would no longer carry the threat of actually going to prison. So legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
Incarceration does not treat addiction; the money spent on incarcerated non-violent drug offenders could be instead used to fund addiction treatment. So all drugs should be legal.

Legalisation of drugs allows for them to be regulated by the state and sold directly to the consumer, increasing purity. I think legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Governments would be able to check what cutting agents are used within the drugs, meaning they will be safer as potentially harmful cutting agents would be banned. That's why all drugs should be legal.
Many [deaths](http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-24581947) attributed to ecstasy \(or MDMA\) use are actually caused by other, unwanted ingredients. I think legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

By legalizing and maintaining the produce of drugs for recreational use, the risk of users getting a hold of a drug falsely advertised for being something else when it's rather poisonous would never happen. I think legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
Strict quality controls will stimulate a fair competition amongst drug suppliers to offer the purest drugs. I believe legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Drugs could be legalised in government shops in which they could be administered through government pharmacists. This would allow governments to control access, much like the [Swedish alcohol trade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systembolaget). I think legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Age restriction does not totally prevent the use of legal drugs among teenagers, as demonstrated by statistics of smokers between [12 and 17](https://www.samhsa.gov/data/report/2017-nsduh-detailed-tables). If this transgression happened in the case of currently illegal drugs in addition to cigarettes and alcohol, this would have even worse consequences. I believe legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.

Legal sellers will be highly scrutinized and won't want to risk losing their license. So legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
Using a fake ID in a legal establishment implies much more work and risk than just buying from the unregulated black market. I believe all drugs should be legal.

This is only a viable strategy for some individuals whom are already close to the legal age, as opposed to a much younger person buying from other young people recruited by the black market. I believe all drugs should be legal.

[Drug prohibition and enforcement](https://books.google.de/books?id=AcvNBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT47&lpg=PT47&dq=illegality+of+drugs+drives+up+the+price&source=bl&ots=LA-lN5bMi-&sig=ACfU3U188KBfP6r7BwldRTsSWoB_M5_FLw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiAjqTq2-XhAhWLLY8KHeDwCFkQ6AEwD3oECAgQAQ#v=onepage&q=illegality%20of%20drugs%20drives%20up%20the%20price&f=false) drive up the price and that causes criminality among users who need to gain enough money to buy them. That's why all drugs should be legal.
Legalization will remove the taboo that drug addiction currently carries with it. As a result, addicts will no longer be a target of prejudice. I believe all drugs should be legal.

Legalizing drugs will not automatically remove the prejudice. If people see those on drugs being violent or a nuisance to society, the prejudice will likely remain. I think legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.

[Alcohol-dependent persons](https://academic.oup.com/alcalc/article/46/2/105/198339) have to face prejudices, although the substance is legal: They are often held responsible for their condition, are subject to social rejection and they are at particular risk for structural discrimination. I believe legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.
Although social prejudice may remain, addicts could seek help far easier if there were no fear of legal repercussions. That's why all drugs should be legal.
While neither seems acceptable, most would rather face prejudice than prison. I believe legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
If legalised, addicts would be forced to buy legally, meaning there is a record of their usage and authorities can intervene if there is an instance of drug abuse. So all drugs should be legal.
Legal drugs would not be the only option; there may still be a market of illegal drugs, for example if it is cheaper than the legal choice. That's why legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.
Even though illegal drugs may still exist if drugs were legalised, there would be far less of them than when illegal drugs were the only option. I believe all drugs should be legal.

If this was true, cartels would already be moving over to newer, patented pharmaceuticals, whose costs of production is dwarfed by market price already. I believe legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Even if criminals are able to offer drugs at lower prices, people would turn to legal drugs because they would not risk prison and they would be sure of the quality of what they're buying. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

The law regulation of the drug's market will standardize the quality of the products, and their safety, creating incentives for the consumers to prefer to deal in the legal market. So all drugs should be legal.

The prevalence of [illicit alcohol](https://www.securingindustry.com/food-and-beverage/alcohol-black-market-accounts-for-sizable-chunk-of-sales-/s104/a7811/#.XRxnXS9XbRY) across some countries in Central and Latin America and Africa is more common than legal alcohol. I believe drugs should remain illegal.

66% of the alcohol consumed in Mozambique, 61% in Uganda, and 56% in Cameron is [illicit](https://www.securingindustry.com/food-and-beverage/alcohol-black-market-accounts-for-sizable-chunk-of-sales-/s104/a7811/#.XRxnXS9XbRY). That's why legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.

Many Canadian cigarettes are [smuggled back](https://www.publicsafety.gc.ca/cnt/rsrcs/pblctns/archive-stts-cntrbnd-tbcc/index-en.aspx) into Canada. That's why legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.
The reason for black market chemicals to be cheaper, is that the black market doesn't care about cost incurring legal restrictions and taxes. I think legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.
Education and information campaigns could be funded by taxes on the drugs themselves. So legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
Education and information might not be enough to ensure thoughtful drug use. I think legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.

Although education and information on the harmful side effects of [smoking](https://edition.cnn.com/2014/01/11/health/still-smoking/index.html) have been around for decades, millions of people still smoke. So legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.

Prohibition clearly isn't enough either, and all but ensures that honest education and information becomes impossible, making it exaggerated and ineffective. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Under current laws, these people are being punished for something that this claim suggests they are unable to refrain from doing. If it's not a choice, then we shouldn't punish people for it. Removing the threat of punishment would also encourage people to get treatment. I believe legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

In the same way that people sign contracts in which they voluntarily limit their freedom for a certain amount of time, a person who chooses freely to take drugs is choosing to limit their self-control freely. In either case, the initial choice is still a free choice. So all drugs should be legal.
Both of these "contracts" are often initiated under desperate circumstances or by ill informed people. That's why legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.
Drug use is not the same as drug addiction. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

[Psychedelics](https://psychedelictimes.com/psychedelic-therapy/are-psychedelics-addictive/) like LSD, Mushrooms and DMT don't lead to [addiction](http://psychedelics.com/psychedelic-drug-addiction/). Even MDMA usually does not lead to addiction. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Psychedelics are often used for [one-off, recreational and spiritual](https://www.livescience.com/61902-psychedelic-drugs-change-personality.html) experiences. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

The lack of addictive qualities in drugs does not equate to an absence of significant negative health impacts from their use. For example, despite lacking addictive qualities, LSD might may induce [schizophrenia](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6870484), as well as immediate or [delayed psychosis](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140673670902205). I think drugs should remain illegal.
Justifying a ban because it provides people with more autonomy is an inherent contradiction. I think all drugs should be legal.
Numerous events have an equal impact on moral judgments; This should not be the reason for the ban on drug use. That's why all drugs should be legal.
[Sleep deprivation](https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/03/070301081831.htm) negatively affects moral judgment and decision-making. So all drugs should be legal.

Most entertainments, TV shows, [advertisements](https://www.academia.edu/8844318/Advertisings_Impact_on_Morality_in_Society_Influencing_Habits_and_Desires_of_Consumers), and political campaigns also affect rational and moral thinking. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

But we don't make moral judgements all the time every day. We all need to stop thinking clearly and rationally every now and then, for activities including but not limited to play, fun, pleasure, love, chilling out, taking a load off… I believe all drugs should be legal.
Sobriety may be required for the optimal exercise of rational moral agency; however, it is not required for the generell exercise of rational moral agency. That's why all drugs should be legal.

[High individuals](https://philosophynow.org/issues/113/On_Moral_Arguments_Against_Recreational_Drug_Use) know the difference between right and wrong and can understand when they are hurting others. I think legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Drug use, in moderation, doesn't violate Kant's [categorical imperative](https://www.theatlantic.com/daily-dish/archive/2010/02/kant-doesnt-care-if-you-get-high/189868/) if drugs were legalized. That's why all drugs should be legal.
A society where everyone consumes moderate amounts of drugs wouldn't be much different than the societies of today. I think all drugs should be legal.
The responsible use of drugs for recreational purposes does not harm others and therefore can not be considered immoral. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Drug use correlates with criminality, thievery, and risky sexual behavior. Responsibility is a state that is easily bypassed when you enter the flow of the drug world. I think drugs should remain illegal.

In the last few years, a number of reports have appeared suggesting a link between alcohol or drug use and [sexual behavior](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2585544/), such as unprotected intercourse, that is known to place an individual at higher risk for HIV infection. So drugs should remain illegal.

Studies on drug users show that criminality among [adults](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5608072/) \(both men and women\) and [young people](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4919962/) rates higher than on people that don't use drugs. [The National Institute on Drug Abuse](https://www.drugabuse.gov/publications/principles-drug-abuse-treatment-criminal-justice-populations/introduction) of USA states the same thing. I believe drugs should remain illegal.
An Indian based study shows that substance consumption highly relate to [juvenile delinquency.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4919962/) So legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.
It's people's own choice whether to be moral or not. That's why all drugs should be legal.
Under the influence of drugs, users are more likely to commit immoral acts. So legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.
"Giving up" is preferable to endlessly pursuing an unobtainable goal. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
Drug use will not cease regardless of the legal status. So legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

[The use of psychoactive substances](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3202501/) has been a part of human culture for thousands of years; drugs have been used for religious, medical or recreational purposes. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

[Entheogenic drugs](https://maps.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5468), such as psychedelics, have been used throughout human history for many benefits in evolutionary growth and cognitive development. So all drugs should be legal.

Illegality over the last century has halted research on the many new psychoactive substances that have been discovered in that time \(as well as traditional ones\). So legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Studies suggest that certain hallucinogens have long term effects on behaviour, [rehabilitating criminals](https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/29/world/americas/a-hallucinogenic-tea-time-for-some-brazilian-prisoners.html) and [treating depression](https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/oct/13/magic-mushrooms-reboot-brain-in-depressed-people-study). For decades, these studies have been prevented by legislation. So all drugs should be legal.

Psilocybin has been recognized by the FDA as a ['breakthrough therapy'](https://reason.com/blog/2018/10/25/fda-recognizes-psilocybin-as-breakthroug) for treating depression, especially depression related to a terminal illness. I believe all drugs should be legal.
Many drugs that are currently illegal have been and are important social tools. I think all drugs should be legal.

Opiates have a [rich history](https://www.history.com/topics/crime/history-of-heroin-morphine-and-opiates) of recreational use, with the Ancient Sumerians calling it "The Joy Plant". That's why all drugs should be legal.

[Marijuana](https://www.cnbc.com/2010/04/19/Marijuana-In-America:-History,-Culture-And-People.html) has a deep history in North America with [religion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cannabis_and_religion) and even a current religious tradition of [Rastafarianism](https://pointsadhsblog.wordpress.com/2015/06/11/the-use-of-marijuana-in-the-rastafari-religion/). It is also a valuable [social](https://www.marketwatch.com/story/millennials-appear-to-like-cannabis-more-than-booze-2018-09-26) tool and has many benefits for the [community](http://www.sfexaminer.com/cannabis-dispensaries-good-community/). That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

[Coca](https://www.nationalgeographic.com/archaeology-and-history/magazine/2016/11-12/daily-life-coca-inca-andes-south-america/) leaf has a deep religious, cultural and community history all over South America with a current vibrant culture in [Peru](https://theculturetrip.com/south-america/peru/articles/the-untold-story-behind-the-religious-beginnings-of-the-coca-leaf/). It is used as medicine, in social settings and was considered a vessel to communicate with the Gods. Pachamama is a current religious ceremony that still uses the leaf. That's why all drugs should be legal.

[Social](https://theconversation.com/what-do-young-people-gain-from-drug-use-18878) and [community](https://theconversation.com/drug-use-can-have-social-benefits-and-acknowledging-this-could-improve-rehabilitation-93978) benefits of using many illicit substances including but not limited to cocaine, marijuana, ecstasy and LSD. [Many](https://ndarc.med.unsw.edu.au/sites/default/files/ndarc/resources/TR.228.pdf) consider these drugs to be great bonding experiences and an overwhelmingly positive social force. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

The consumption of psychoactive substances creates religious and transcendental [experiences](https://www.sciencealert.com/how-religion-led-to-humanity-s-love-for-drugs): both are a relevant part of human evolution and significantly shaped human culture. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

If psychoactive medicine were properly administered and regulated, it could function in this religious/transcendental function, without causing personal and societal dysfunction. So legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Rational discussion of the costs and benefits of smoking tobacco and negative ads led a lot of people to decide it isn't worth doing. All without prohibiting it. I think all drugs should be legal.

Legalization of drugs will make people aware of their consequences \(having a prospectus like medicine with known pros and cons - like marijuana for medical usage\). So all drugs should be legal.

Something being illegal makes the entire area "tainted." Talking about how to do something illegal is seen as encouraging said activity, and "sending the wrong signals." So all drugs should be legal.
Having any positive impacts at all is not to be conflated with being a net positive, or fully positive. So drugs should remain illegal.
Creativity can be stimulated through the use of drugs. Drugs could help us to live in a more creative dynamic society. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Drugs are an experience that can build character. So all drugs should be legal.
Drugs can give individuals false perceptions of reality, inducing potentially negative behaviour. So drugs should remain illegal.

Cocaine addiction causes [higher impulsivity](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5817335/), meaning sufferers are more likely to engage in risky behaviour such as gambling. That's why drugs should remain illegal.
The legalization of all drugs could make people live and learn life as it is. Bad decisions are a part of life. I believe all drugs should be legal.
Drugs relate with [lower social skills](https://www.gatewayfoundation.org/substance-abuse-treatment-programs/effects-of-drug-abuse/) and antisocial behavior. I think drugs should remain illegal.
Legalization will facilitate access to drugs. I think legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.
A more substantial part of society will be exposed to the harmful and dangerous side effects of drugs. That's why legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.

A legalization of all drugs may lead to many [replacing](https://theintercept.com/2018/04/20/marijuana-legalization-alcohol-consumption/) part of their alcohol consumption with healthier drugs. That's why all drugs should be legal.

[Alcohol](https://theconversation.com/alcohol-leads-to-more-violence-than-other-drugs-but-youd-never-know-from-the-headlines-72281) is responsible for more violence and harm than any other drug. I think all drugs should be legal.

Research suggests that [two-thirds](https://www.verywell.com/domestic-abuse-and-alcohol-62643) of incidents of domestic violence happen while the perpetrator is under the influence of alcohol. I think all drugs should be legal.

Drugs can be used to abuse others or commit crimes. I think drugs should remain illegal.

Citizens would not have to worry about potentially losing their career over using a substance for a medical condition. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Legalisation will at length normalize drug use, which can lead to excess use as with alcohol \(drinking games, binge drinking\) which can be far more dangerous when done with hard drugs. I think drugs should remain illegal.

In countries where using marijuana is legal or allowed, [smoking games](https://honestmarijuana.com/weed-games/) have arisen to get more stoned/high more quickly. That's why drugs should remain illegal.
Due to abundance and normalization, people could enjoy other drugs like the enjoy a glass of wine. I believe all drugs should be legal.

Legalization will allow people to choose the safer drug. Currently law abiding citizens typically choose alcohol or tobacco which is easily in the more dangerous category. I believe all drugs should be legal.
The decision to use drugs should rest solely with individuals. I think all drugs should be legal.

If the pursuit of freedom and promotion of liberty are goals of a state, then the laws surrounding drug use are incompatible with freedom and liberty. I think legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
In a truly free society self regulation should be our privilege. You are free to not use drugs, and you should be just as free to use them. So all drugs should be legal.
Drug use has a negative effect on freedom and, therefore, ought to be contained. That's why drugs should remain illegal.
[The human right to personal autonomy](http://www.corteidh.or.cr/tablas/r26750.pdf) should include the freedom to take drugs. I believe legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
Many constitutions and legal frameworks promote personal autonomy. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
[Personal autonomy](https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/personal_autonomy) is not a fundamental right in the US constitution. I think legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.

In 1975, the [Supreme Court of Alaska](http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/view/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780195334340.001.0001/acprof-9780195334340-chapter-8) ruled that there was a constitutional right to smoke marijuana in one's home. I believe all drugs should be legal.
The prohibition of drugs at no time endangers the personal autonomy of the individual. I believe drugs should remain illegal.

Bodily integrity - a part of personal autonomy - is defined as '[the right to self governance over one's own body without external influence or coercion.](http://www.soc.ucsb.edu/sexinfo/article/bodily-autonomy)' This suggests that the right to bodily integrity protects individuals from external coercion; it does not, however, empower them to use illegal substances. That's why drugs should remain illegal.
The right to bodily integrity protects individuals from [forced labor, slavery or torture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bodily_integrity). So legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.
In many legal frameworks, the use of drugs is not considered a criminal offense. Only production, commerce, ownership and distribution of drugs are typically illegal. So drugs should remain illegal.
In Uruguay, possession of drugs for personal use [is legal](https://www.tni.org/es/node/16660). I think legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.

[In German law](http://www.emcdda.europa.eu/countries/drug-reports/2018/germany/drug-laws-and-drug-law-offences_en), the use of drugs is not mentioned as a legal offense. I believe drugs should remain illegal.
The Federal Government \(US\) has no constitutional authority to regulate what citizens choose to put in their bodies. I believe drugs should remain illegal.
Constitutions can be amended by the Federal Government to suit their policies. I think legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

A [Constitutional Amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eighteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution) had to be voted on for the prohibition of alcohol. That's why all drugs should be legal.

There is [no mention](https://www.leafly.com/news/cannabis-101/cannabis-and-the-constitution-a-brief-history-of-cannabis-in-the-u-s) of cannabis, nor any other drugs, in the Constitution. That's why drugs should remain illegal.

According to [Human Right Watch](https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/06/04/americas-decriminalize-personal-use-drugs), subjecting people to disproportionate criminal sanctions for the personal use of drugs "infringes on their autonomy". So all drugs should be legal.
Taking drugs is not always a victimless crime, as drug users can harm others. I think drugs should remain illegal.
Drug users will encourage other people, who do not know how to handle drugs and/or aren't smart and/or mature enough to try it. I believe drugs should remain illegal.
In a free society, drug users must be free to share their perspective with others, and other people must be free to decide for themselves how they want to act. That's why all drugs should be legal.
They already do this with alcohol or cigarettes, which hasn't caused our society to collapse. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
People may drive under the influence of drugs or make other decisions with public consequences. I think drugs should remain illegal.
Drugs are already [easy to get](https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/drugs-buy-how-easy-buy-ice-cream-takeaway-cocaine-crack-marijuana-a8142191.html). So all drugs should be legal.

Legalizing marijuana will increase the risk of accidents on the highways \(and indeed has in [Washington, Oregon and Colorado](http://fortune.com/2018/10/18/legal-marijuana-car-accidents-study/) where it has been legalized\) causing harm to others. I believe drugs should remain illegal.

Decriminalization would encourage the implementation of a broader scope of impairment detection devices. This would cause users to think twice about driving impaired on substances they believe wouldn't be detected using current methods. I believe all drugs should be legal.
Driving a car or operating machinery while under the influence of drugs is illegal. I think legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
That's already true in [most states \(USA\)](https://www.ghsa.org/state-laws/issues/drug%20impaired%20driving) So legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
The [relatives](https://novarecoverycenter.com/drug-use/parental-drug-abuse/) of addicts are negatively impacted by their addiction. I believe drugs should remain illegal.

Nearly all negative effects of addicts on their families are not fueled by the addiction itself, but the fact that the drug they are addicted to is made illegal by the ban on drugs. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

It's not a given that the low well-being of drug users' families are a result of the drug use. The confounding variable is likely mental health issues. It's possible \(and sometimes preferable\) to solve the mental health issues, while not stopping the drug use. I think all drugs should be legal.

A parent's drugs addiction can cause a child to suffer emotional harm and a lack of future stability as it can reduce the parent's life expectancy, causing them to die young. I believe drugs should remain illegal.
Knowledge that a friend or relative is using drugs can cause significant psychological stress to a caring or sensitive individual. I think drugs should remain illegal.

It's entirely possible for the issue to be intolerance and lack of understanding from the family itself. In those cases, the issue is the reaction of the family, and not the drug use or drug users themselves. That's why all drugs should be legal.
This stress would be reduced if the drugs were legal because it would remove the threat of legal danger to any concerned person. I believe legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Such stress might be irrational, especially when it's related to unproblematic drug use. In that case, the psychological stress is the fault of the persons irrational beliefs. I think legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

Some people may become psychologically stressed about a friend/relative coming out as gay, or an atheist as well. That doesn't mean the friend/relative did anything wrong. I think legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
Someone experiencing elevated stress levels isn't a good enough justification to limit other people's freedom by force. So all drugs should be legal.
Taking the stigma and secrecy away from drug taking would mean family and friends would notice drug abuse earlier and be able to intervene. That's why all drugs should be legal.

It depends on the drug. Some drugs, like MDMA, make people exhibit more [prosocial behaviour and more empathy, and thus presumably would make them less predisposed to violence.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24097374) So all drugs should be legal.

[Smoking](https://www.cancer.org/cancer/cancer-causes/tobacco-and-cancer/secondhand-smoke.html) puts the drugs into the air, meaning non-consenting people take the drug as well. I think legalization of drugs is a really bad idea.
Governments manipulate citizens by spreading biased information about drugs and thereby interfering with their choices. That's why all drugs should be legal.
Historically, the US government has released inaccurate or untruthful information about drugs in an attempt to stop the public from using them. I believe legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

The US government has [previously supported](https://www.ozy.com/flashback/when-the-government-said-marijuana-made-you-crazy/88232) the claim that marijuana use causes individuals to rape and murder others, or commit suicide. I believe legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.

[Genesis 1:29](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Genesis+1%3A29&version=KJV) can be interpreted to suggest that it is [an individual's right](https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/alysonmartin/cannabis-reform-and-religion-in-the-south) to use marijuana. That's why all drugs should be legal.

A large portion of the public is irresponsible. Giving everyone the opportunity to use \(or abuse\) drugs would have negative consequences on these individuals. That's why drugs should remain illegal.
True freedom of choice means that individuals must face the consequences of their actions, whether they are good or bad. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
Safety of irresponsible people shouldn't come at the expense of freedom of responsible people. So all drugs should be legal.

[Many drug users](https://www.drugabuse.gov/publications/drugs-brains-behavior-science-addiction/drug-misuse-addiction) do not consider the negative repercussions of drug use and are convinced they can easily control their use. So drugs should remain illegal.
The legalisation of drugs will improve overall safety by containing criminal opportunities. That's why all drugs should be legal.
Legalization will help law enforcement agencies. I believe all drugs should be legal.
Drugs being legal shifts the focus of the police from investigating crimes where individuals damaged others instead of themselves. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
Ending the war on drugs will reduce [police casualties](https://www.vox.com/2014/10/29/7083371/swat-no-knock-raids-police-killed-civilians-dangerous-work-drugs). I think all drugs should be legal.

As with the [legalization of prostitution in New South Wales in Australia](http://www.scarletalliance.org.au/issues/swedish_model/10reasons_07), legalising drugs would remove an important source of corruption in the police, the government, and the judiciary. That's why legalization of drugs is a pretty good idea.
